Posted By: AshToMoutHound (4/3/2012 4:31:27 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I got into Magic before [Go for the Throat](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Go for the Throat) and [Doom Blade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doom Blade) existed. Terror has always been what I think of when I think of spot removal. I used to imprint this on [Isochron Scepter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Isochron Scepter) and kill things *every* turn. Used to be my favorite card, still is way up there.  
5/5
posts.html:

5/5

Posted By: gman92 (2/22/2012 3:30:11 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Ahh Terror. Quite the staple in its day, very effective, and yet when R&D finally asked the question "why is this card so complicated" most people had no answer.  
  
As much as I like the "can't regenerate" part of Terror, it's almost never come up whenever I've used the spell. I suppose if your going up against a green deck running a lot of regenerating creatures it might come in handy, but most of the time just destroying the creature takes care of the problem. In the current environment, half the time I'll take the ability to hit any artifact creature on the board versus ensuring something won't regenerate. Coincidentally, my black decks usually run two [Doom Blade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doom Blade)s and two [Terror](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Terror)s.

Posted By: intothevoid (2/3/2011 6:40:20 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Quit comparing Terror to Doomblade! Doomblade is a functional reprint of Terror, but R&D dropped the non-artifact component because they wanted to do more sets with an artifact theme (Alara, Scars), and the regeneration component because R&D likes regeneration in Limited (except in Scars).
posts.html:
Quit comparing Terror to Doomblade! Doomblade is a functional reprint of Terror, but R&D dropped the non-artifact component because they wanted to do more sets with an artifact theme (Alara, Scars), and the regeneration component because R&D likes regeneration in Limited (except in Scars).

Posted By: Artsy_Wumpus (4/6/2011 10:47:48 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Well, there might be [strictly better choices](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=190535) now.  
But during my early days of Magic, both the name and the artwork of this oddly worded old card that popped up with various printings in my opponent's deck who otherwise played with comparably newer cards that did have an expansion symbol at least, did have something iconic and mysterious. This was one aspect that made me love this game :D
